Dutch[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle Dutch wie, from Old Dutch wie, from Proto-Germanic *hwaz, from Proto-Indo-European *kÊ·os.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /Ê‹i/
  • audio
    		(file)
  • Hyphenation: wie
  • Rhymes: -i

Pronoun[edit]

wie

  1. (interrogative, subjective or objective) who, whom
    Wie is daar?
    Whoâ€™s there?
    Wie heb jij gezien?
    Whom did you see?
  2. (relative, subjective or objective) who, whom; the one who, whoever
    Wie dit leest is geletterd.
    The one who reads this is literate.
    De receptionist aan wie ik het pakket heb afgegeven, werkte er pas net.
    The receptionist to whom I handed over the parcel had only recently started working there.

Derived terms[edit]

  • wien
  • wiens
  • wier

Descendants[edit]

  • Afrikaans: wie

Anagrams[edit]

  • wei

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German wie, a merger of two interrelated forms: 1.) Old High German hwio, from older hwÄ“o, from Proto-Germanic *hwaiwa; cognate with Gothic ğˆğŒ°ğŒ¹ğ…ğŒ° (Æ•aiwa). 2.) Old High German hwÄ“, hwie, from Proto-Germanic *hwÄ“; cognate with Gothic ğˆğŒ´ (Æ•Ä“). The latter is a variant of Proto-Germanic *hwÄ«, whence English why, and is further a fossiled instrumental case of *hwaz, *hwat (â€œwho, whatâ€). Form 1 is also related to this stem.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /viË/
  		• (file)
  • Rhymes: -iË

Adverb[edit]

wie

  1. how
    Wie groÃŸ bist du?
    How tall are you?
    Ich weiÃŸ nicht, wie die Katze hereingekommen ist.
    I don't know how the cat got in.
    Wie wunderbar!
    How wonderful!

Related terms[edit]

  • wieso
  • wie dem auch sei
  • wie geht es

Conjunction[edit]

wie

  1. like
    Freunde sind wie Sterne in der Nacht.
    Friends are like stars in the night.
  2. as
    Wie ihr wisst, bin ich in Dortmund aufgewachsen.
    As you know, I grew up in Dortmund.
    Ich bin so schnell wie du.
    Iâ€™m as fast as you are.
  3. (colloquial, nonstandard) than
    Der Junge ist grÃ¶ÃŸer wie sein Vater.
    The boy is taller than his father.
  4. (chiefly colloquial) when (referring to the past)
    Ich hab ihn gesehen, wie ich in KÃ¶ln war.
    I saw him when I was in Cologne.
    Wie ich zur TÃ¼r herauskomme, steht da mein alter Schulfreund.
    When I came out the door, my old school-day friend was standing in front of me.

Synonyms[edit]

  • (when, than): als (more properly standard)
